Award.AwardTitle: U.S. Young Observer Program for the 2013 and 2015 Congress and General Assembly of the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Katherine W Bowman, Katherine Bailey Mathae and Kathryn Hughes of the National Academy of Sciences are supported in an award from the Division of Chemistry to support the Young Observer Program for the 2013 Congress and General Assembly of the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC). Approximately 12 early-to-mid career scientists (under the age of 45) will attend the 45th IUPAC Congress and 47th IUPAC General Assembly (Turkey, 2013). The Young Observers will obtaine travel grants as well as associated mentoring, networking and career development opportunities. The IUPAC Young Observer program has been in operation since 1977 and has introduced approximately 200 scientists to the international issues and progress in the field of chemistry.

The objectives of the IUPAC Young Observer Program include provide networking and mentoring opportunities that foster interactions of the participants with leading scientists in their field, helping to nurture a future generation of chemistry leaders, providing opportunities for sharing research in a global forum from across the chemical sciences, and fostering international collaborations between U.S. chemists and their international peers. The Young Observer program will enable those who might not otherwise be able to attend the Congress and General Assembly to do so, encouraging the participation of a strong pool of U.S. chemistry talent at these meetings and in IUPAC activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The US sponsored 12 Young Observers (YOs) to attend the World Chemistry Congress and General Assembly in Istanbul Turkey in 2013 with this grant. Ultimately 11 early- and mid-career chemists were able to attend the event. They are:

  • Deborah Aruguette, National Science Foundation
  • Ronald Castellano, University of Florida
  • Markus Etzkorn, The University of North Carolina at Charlotte
  • Ilia Guzei, University of Wisconsin-Madison
  • Malika Jeffries-El, Iowa State University
  • Wibe Albe de Jong, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory
  • Brian Korgel, University of Texas at Austin
  • Robin Macaluso, University of Northern Colorado
  • Christine Straut, Sandia National Laboratories
  • Izabela Tworowska, RadioMedix Inc.
  • Lewis Whitehead, Novartis Institutes for Medical Research

The YOs were expected to attend governance meetings for the organization, participate in scientific sessions of the Congress, and attend both the World Chemistry Leadership Meeting. In addition to the governance events, every YO submitted an abstract for a presentation or paper at the 2013 Congress. Young Observers were provided with many opportunities for both formal and informal networking with US and international scientists. Each YO was assigned a mentor drawn from the US delegation to the IUPAC.

At every General Assembly, IUPAC hosts a World Chemistry Leadership Meeting (WCLM) that focuses on a specific topic. In 2013 the topic was the future of IUPAC, and the Young Observers were invited specifically to provide feedback and structure to IUPAC on their observations and hopes for the organization. The meeting was summarized in Chemistry International in January 2014 (Michael Droescher (2014). World Chemistry Young Leadership Meeting: Echoes from the 2013 Meeting. 36. (1). Chemistry International, 36. 24. Published. No. No. DOI. 10.1515/ci.2014.36.1.24.), and the YO's participation and findings were summarized in a blog post titled The Future of Chemistry, by the Young Observers #WCLM13 – Conclusions: http://www.yourformula.eu/internalposts/the-future-of-chemistry-by-the-young-observers-wclm13-conclusions/

The meeting provided three clear opportunities for professional development. First, this activity placed the US chemists in a position to meet scientists with similar interests and professional activities from around the world. As reported by a survey of the YOs after the event, the chemists selected felt that participation in the event increased the likelihood of collaboration with both US and non-US scientists and reported that participation increased their capacity to hold leadership positions in the chemistry community in the future. Since the 2013 meeting, a number of YOs have maintained engagement in IUPAC activities and participation in other international activities to support chemists and their communities.
